story.kicker_image_caption: Prince was found unresponsive in his Minnesota home in April 2016. Picture courtesy: Reuters
story.storykicker: Prince "died of an accidental, self-administered overdose of an opioid painkiller," says a medical examiner.
story.storybody:
American pop star Prince was found unresponsive in his Minnesota home late April this year; months later, the cause of his death has finally been revealed.

The Purple Rain singer died of an accidental, self-administered overdose of an opioid painkiller, the county medical examiner has said in a death report. The details of the report came to light on Thursday.

The Midwest Medical Examiner's Office in Anoka County, Minnesota, had been investigating the legendary singer's death since he was discovered in an elevator in his home and studio on April 21.

Also read: Was Prince diagnosed with AIDS six months before his death?

"The decedent self-administered fentanyl," the medical examiner's report said, listing the cause of death as "fentanyl toxicity" and noting that it was accidental.

Soon after Prince's death, a number of reports and claims started doing the rounds--with one report claiming that the iconic singer was diagnosed with AIDS six months before his demise; while some others claimed that he might have killed himself. Later reports ruled out that possibility.

Also read: US pop singer Prince found dead at Minnesota home

Soon after Prince's demise, two of his albums--The Very Best Of and Purple Rain--grabbed the top two spots at Billboard 200 albums chart.

Despite rumoured reports, investigations into Prince's death have always been centred around painkillers, since prescription opioid medication was found at the scene.

(With inputs from Reuters)

story.shortheadline: Legendary singer Prince died of opioid overdose, says medical examiner
